column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat|salience|identity|centering
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent

#Summary1=(human1) In an appeal by Atlantic Lottery Corporation against Douglas Babstock et al., attorney Julie Rosenthal argues that the Newfoundland and Labrador Court of Appeal's ruling that negligence can amount to wrongdoing in the absence of loss or injury is new and meets no unmet societal need, while contradicting precedent from the law of negligence, and should therefore be overturned.

#Summary2=(claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) The case involves a motion to strike in Atlantic Lottery Corporation v. Babstock, where the key issue is whether the Newfoundland Court of Appeal erred in recognizing "waiver of tort" as a new cause of action allowing disgorgement without proof of causally-linked loss or injury.

#Summary3=(gpt4o) In the case of Atlantic Lottery Corporation, Inc. v. Douglas Babstock et al., Julie Rosenthal argues for the appellant that the Newfoundland and Labrador Court of Appeal erred in recognizing a cause of action for waiver of tort without causally linked loss, claiming it contradicts established negligence law that requires actual damage for a tort to exist.

#Summary4=(Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct) The respondent's counsel Julie Rosenthal argues that waiver of tort is a new cause of action for disgorgement for wrongdoing and that the Newfoundland and Labrador Court of Appeal erred in recognizing it, as it is incompatible with the law of negligence and lacks internal coherence and specificity.

#Summary5=(Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct) The argument presented by Atlantic Lottery Corporation seeks to invalidate the newly recognized cause of action for disgorgement of profits based on a breach of duty without causally linked loss, asserting it is incompatible with negligence law and lacks coherence, and requests the court to rule it unlawful.
#Text=Good morning to all .

#Text=In the case of Atlantic Lottery Corporation , Inc. et al. against Douglas Babstock et al. , for the appellant , Atlantic Lottery Corporation , Inc. : Julie Rosenthal , Mike Eizenga , Sarah Stoddar- Stoddart , I 'm sorry , Jonathan Bell . [ … ]
#Text=For the intervener , British Columbia Lottery Corporation : K. Michael Stevens , Shannon Ramsey , and Aubin Calvert .
#Text=For the respondents , Douglas Babstock et al. : Kirk M. Bart and Celeste Pollock .
#Text=Miss Rosenthal ?
#Text=Thank you .
#Text=To give you a sense of how we 're dividing our argument , I will be addressing the issue of waiver of tort , the new cause of action , we say , of disgorgement for wrongdoing .
#Text=My colleague , Mr. Eizenga , will address the Criminal Code issue and unjust enrichment .

#Text=And Mr. Kelly , who acts for the remaining appellants , will address the requirement that any order of disgorgement of profits must be limited to those profits that result from , or that are causally linked to the breach of contract or other wrongdoing at issue .
#Text=And we have agreed to divide our time 20 20 20 .
#Text=And I wish to start by clarifying a point of terminology , and it relates to the use of the term waiver of tort .
#Text=And the reason I wish to clarify it is that you will hear the respondent 's counsel say waiver of tort is nothing new , that it 's an old cause of action .
#Text=And therefore what the Newfoundland and Labrador Court of Appeal did is -- is nothing out of the ordinary .
#Text=But what I say that argument obscures is the fact that waiver of tort can be used in two quite different ways , and t- to refer to two different concepts .

#Text=The first is , it may refer to an old , old common law concept , a construct that would allow a plaintiff to obtain a gains based remedy but for a completed cause of action , and traditionally it was uh applied with respect to two causes of action , in particular proprietary causes of action and trespass or conversion .
#Text=But what I wish to emphasize is that that old construct was applied where the plaintiff could prove a completed cause of action .
#Text=It remains an open question whether that construct should be expanded to allow for gains - based remedies for other types of claims .
#Text=This is this is your case to plead , but you have dived headlong into the weeds .
#Text=You have not told us what our task is here today .
#Text=Now that 's up to you , whether you want to frame it in a more general sense or not .
#Text=But it would assist me , at least in terms of what it is , in a general sense , we 're being asked to decide today .

#Text=So what I am asking you to decide today is the second -- relates to the second , and what I say is the new and much narrower meaning of of waiver of tort , which is what the Newfoundland and Labrador Court of Appeal did , which is to say there exists a cause of action that comprises a breach of a duty of care without causally linked loss or injury .
#Text=And that , I say , is very new .

#Text=It was first suggested by the Ontario courts back in Sirhan , and it 's the Newfoundland and Labrador Court of Appeal that , for the first time has affirmatively recognized that as a cause of action .
#Text=And what I would ask this court to do is to clarify , to correct that error and say that there is no such cause of action .
#Text=I take it this is a motion to strike .
#Text=That 's what I mean by general propositions .
#Text=It arose at first instance on a motion to strike .
#Text=Correct .
#Text=And so I have -- there are really two main reasons I say why the proposed cause of action should be definitively ruled by this court , not to be sound at law .
#Text=And the first is really a doctrinal point , which is that it is fundamentally at odds with the law of negligence .
#Text=And the second is that even on its own terms , it lacks internal coherence and is impermissibly vague , I say , and unworkable .
#Text=And for those reasons , the commentators have opposed it .
#Text=It would put -- no other common law jurisdiction has even considered such a cause of action .
#Text=And fundamentally , I say it does n't answer any unmet societal need .

#Text=So turning to the first point , which is the the incompatibility with the law of negligence , that law , of course , has been settled for close to 100 years , and it could n't be clearer that breach of a duty of care without loss or injury does not give rise to a cause of action .
#Text=That 's set out in Moran and Pyle .
#Text=If needed , that 's in my condensed book at Tab 3 .
#Text=And what I wish to emphasize is that this court has made it abundantly clear that careless behavior alone is not wrongful .
#Text=It is only the loss or injury that makes it wrongful .
#Text=And if I could direct the court 's attention , please , to Tab 4 of our condensed book .
#Text=This is the decision in Ratych and Bloomer .
#Text=Reading from line E a quote from Lord Diplock and Browning and War Office :
#Text=" A person who acts without reasonable care does no wrong in law .
